resources.string: EcotoPatasites \nFive species of louse infest cattle: the biting or chewing louse
Treatment \nUse a pour-on synthetic pyrethroid preparation such as deitamerthrin
Prevention \nAll cattle in direct contact must be treated
Warts \nCattle warts are caused by an infectious and contagious virus (bovine papilloma virus; BPV) that spreads via contact from infected cattle to non-infected cattle
Treatment \nIsolate affected cattle to reduce the chance of spread. Warts can be removed surgically, or by tying a tight ligature around the base, depending on the number, type, size and locations.
Prevention \nIsolate affected cattle to reduce the chance of spread
Lumpy Skin \nLumpy skin disease is an infectious disease in cattle caused by a virus of the family Poxviridae, also known as Neethling virus
Treatment \nThere is no treatment for the virus, so prevention by vaccination is the most effective means of control
Prevention \nVaccination is the most effective means of control, and live homologous vaccines containing a Neethling-like strain of LSDV are recommended

Pink Eye \nPinkeye, also known as infectious bovine keratoconjunctivitis (IBK), is one of the most common diseases of beef cattle in Virginia. It is a highly contagious disease, causing inflammation of the cornea (the clear outer layer) and conjunctiva (the pink membrane lining the eyelids) of the eye
Treatment \nFly control using ear tags and pour-on insecticides is never absolute and repeated treatments prove costly
Prevention \nOutbreaks of IBK may occur after the introduction of purchased stock therefore, whenever possible, all new stock should be managed separately as one group away from the main herd

Lameness \nThe best all-encompassing definition of lameness includes any abnormality which causes a cow to change the way that she walks, and can be caused by a range of foot and leg conditions, themselves caused by disease, management or environmental factors
Treatment \nDutch 5 step claw trimming - steps 1-3 correct claw shape and confirm the sole ulcer.Anti-inflammatory drugs

Prevention \nGood nutrition is fundamentally important for the general health and productivity of dairy cows. However, there are no proven direct links with acidosis or laminitis. Therefore, methods for reducing sole ulcers by altering diets alone, should focus on minimising body condition score loss. Other preventative measures include reducing standing on concrete, particularly at calving
